Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Exploring Beginning Mathematics Teachers' Career Patterns

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recruiting and retaining effective mathematics teachers has been emphasized in national reports as a top priority in educational policy initiatives. Research indicates that the average turnover rate is nearly 23% for beginning teachers (compared to 15% for veteran instructors); turnover rates for beginning mathematics teachers are even higher. Many mathematics teachers with three or fewer years' experience begin their careers in high-needs schools and often transfer to low-need schools at their first opportunity. This reshuffling, as effective teachers move from high- to low-need schools, exacerbates the unequal distribution of teacher quality, with important implications for disparities in student achievement. Research increasingly provides insights into the magnitude of mathematics teacher turnover, but has identified only a limited number of factors that influence teachers' career decisions and often fails to capture the complexity of the teacher labor market. Thus, it is essential to understand the features, practices, and local contexts that are relevant to beginning teachers' career decisions in order to identify relevant strategies for retention. This project will address these issues, building evidence-based theories of ways to improve the quality and equity of the distribution of the mathematics teaching workforce. This support for an early CAREER scholar in mathematics policy will enhance capacity to address issues in the future.

This work will be guided by three research objectives, to: (1) explore patterns in mathematics teachers' career movements, comparing patterns between elementary and middle school teachers, and between high- and low-need schools; (2) compare qualifications and effectiveness of teachers on different career paths (e.g., movement in/out of school, district, field); and (3) test a conceptual model of how policy-malleable factors influence beginning math teachers' performance improvement and career movements. The PI will use large-scale federal and state longitudinal data on a cohort of teachers who were first-year teachers in 2007-08 and taught mathematics in grades 3-8. Three samples will be analyzed separately and then collectively: a nationally representative sample from the Beginning Teacher Longitudinal Study (about 870 teachers who represent a national population of nearly 85,970); about 4,220 Florida teachers; and about 2,410 North Carolina teachers. In addition, the PI will collaborate with Education Policy Initiative at Carolina (EPIC) at UNC-Chapel Hill to collect new data from the 2015-16 cohort of first-year teachers in NC (about 800 teachers) and follow them for 2 years. The new data collection will provide detailed and reliable measures on the quality of both pre- and in-service teacher supports in order to understand how they may be linked to teachers' career movements and performance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER project integrates research, education, and outreach activities that focus on the improvement and career patterns of mathematics teachers, particularly those who work in high-need K-12 schools that serve minority, poor, or under-performing students. This project uses longitudinal measures from surveys and state administrative databases. Three samples have been analyzed: nationally representative samples from Baccalaureate and Beyond Longitudinal Study (B&B), Schools and Staffing Survey (SASS-TFS), and two state samples from North Carolina and Washington teachers. In addition of using secondary data, this project also collects original survey data from North Carolina beginning teachers to study how teacher preparation may influence teacher growth patterns and their career movements.

Intellectual merit. By integrating findings across locations and over time, this project generates an evidence-based theory on ways to improve the quality and equity of distribution of the mathematics teaching workforce to further improve students’ mathematics learning and to close the achievement gap across schools. First, using B&B studies in 1993, 2000, and 2008, Sun and her co-authors found that schools nationwide were recruiting a greater share of academically skilled college graduates into teaching, and that increases in teachers’ academic skills were especially large in urban school districts that serve predominantly non-white students. On the other hand, the increase in the share of academically skilled teachers coincides with the lower likelihood of non-white teachers being employed. Once teaching, non-white teachers report substantially lower job satisfaction than other teachers. Second, continuing the inquiry of career pathways of teachers of color, Sun used over a decade of data from North Carolina elementary and middle schools and found that Black teachers had significantly lower retention rate than their White counterparts. Black teachers’ likelihood of retention increases with the increase in their observational ratings, math value-added, and reading value-added, but decreases with the increase in science valued-added. Moreover, Black teachers are more likely to stay in schools serving larger proportions of Black students and are more likely to switch to another school serving a higher proportion of Black students. School supports, including school leadership, mentoring, and professional development, further bolster the retention of Black teachers with higher math value-added scores. The findings suggest fruitful policy strategies for retaining and supporting Black math and science teachers. Third, to further explore what policy-malleable factors contribute to teacher effectiveness and retention, our team used statewide completer survey data from North Carolina teacher preparation program completers to assess whether perceptions of preparation quality and opportunities to learn during teacher preparation predict completers’ value-added estimates, evaluation ratings, and retention in their first three years of teaching. Results indicate that preparation experiences focused on creating supportive learning environments predicts beginning teacher effectiveness and retention. Fourth, using decades of school finance, personnel, community neighborhood contexts, school performance, and student information data in WA, Sun and her colleagues have begun to examine the impacts and mechanisms of the increase in teacher salaries on attracting and retaining high-quality math teachers, particularly in low-income districts and schools.

Broader Impacts. This award had yielded high-impact publications. To date, it has published 9 peer-reviewed journal articles, and over 20 conference presentations at national and international levels (e.g., AEFP, AERA, SREE, APPAM). This award supports the launch of Education Policy Analytics Lab at the University of Washington (UW EPAL), which uses interdisciplinary perspectives and research methods to provide cutting-edge educational policy research. The lab’s work seeks to provide meaningful, innovative, and rigorous analysis of data to address pressing educational issues at federal, state, and local levels. Sun uses its website to publish manuscripts, working papers, research briefs, and course syllabi. EPAL has also trained an interdisciplinary research team of students at graduate and undergraduate levels in statistics, education, and computer science. To further broaden the influence of this project to policymakers, Sun has been serving on the Washington State K-12 Data Governance Committee since 2017 to use data and research to inform policy decision-making. Lastly, Sun has actively use public media and social media to disseminate the findings, including but not limited to, the 74 Million, Chalkbeat, Education Week, Seattle Times, webinars, podcasts, twitter, facebook, and youtube.
